intro: Salpiglossis straminea, commonly known as the yellow lollipop flower, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Solanaceae, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its vibrant, tubular flowers that come in shades of yellow, orange, and red. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with hairy stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers are pollinated primarily by hummingbirds, which are attracted to its nectar-rich blooms. Salpiglossis straminea is valued in gardens for its ornamental appeal and ease of cultivation.
